slides.text: COMMENSALISM: One species benefits, the other is neither helped nor harmed. Example: Barnacles on a whale. Barnacles get free transportation to food-rich waters. The whale is unaffected. Another: Birds nesting in trees.
slides.mascot_explanation: This next type is "commensalism," where one friend gets something good, but the other friend doesn't really care – it's not better or worse off. Think about barnacles sticking to a whale; the barnacles get a free ride to new food spots, but the whale just keeps swimming like normal, totally unaffected. It’s like having a friend who borrows your pencil but gives it right back and you don’t even notice it’s gone.

slides.text: PARASITISM: One species benefits at the other's expense. Example: Ticks feed on deer blood, weakening the deer. Tapeworms live inside host animals, stealing nutrients. Parasites rarely kill their hosts — a dead host means no more food.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is "parasitism," which is like one friend taking advantage of the other. Ticks on a deer are a good example; the tick gets a meal (blood!), but the deer gets weaker. Parasites usually don't want their host to die because then they'd lose their food source, so it's more like a really annoying freeloading situation.

slides.prompt: Complete three tasks: (1) Sort the 10 symbiosis example cards into mutualism, commensalism, and parasitism. For each, explain your reasoning. (2) Research one symbiotic relationship in depth and create a mini-poster showing: the two species, how they interact, which type of symbiosis it is, and what would happen if the relationship was disrupted. (3) Go outside with a magnifying glass and observe for 10 minutes. Can you find any symbiotic relationships in your local environment? Record observations in your journal.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the scientist! First, you'll sort those example cards into the three types of relationships we just learned about, explaining why you put each one where you did. Then, pick one relationship to research more and make a mini-poster about it. Finally, head outside with your magnifying glass to see if you can spot any of these living-together friendships or freeloading situations happening right in your own backyard or local park and jot down what you see in your journal.

slides.text: Symbiotic relationships show us that ecosystems are built on connections between species. When we damage one species, we affect its partners too. This interconnection is why conservation must consider entire ecosystems, not just individual species.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student define and distinguish the three types of symbiosis, classify real-world examples, and identify potential symbiotic relationships in their local environment?
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this last slide is reminding us that nature is all about connections, like a giant web. When one part of the web gets messed up, it can affect everything else connected to it, which is why protecting nature means looking after all the different living things and how they interact, not just one at a time. You've done a great job learning about these relationships and even getting ready to observe them yourself!

parent_notes: Symbiosis is a fascinating topic that helps children see the natural world as a web of relationships. The outdoor observation activity is particularly valuable — look for lichen on trees (fungus + algae mutualism), bees on flowers, birds following lawnmowers for insects, or moss on rocks. If your child has pets, discuss the human-pet relationship — is it mutualism? The classification activity develops logical thinking as students must analyze who benefits and who is harmed in each relationship. This connects to the broader ecology theme of interconnection.

title: Documentary Photography — Telling Stories with Images
description: Students learn the art of documentary photography, which captures real life to tell stories and raise awareness about social and environmental issues. They study the work of documentary photographers, learn composition techniques, and create a photo essay on a local environmental topic.
instructions:
1. Define documentary photography: capturing real moments to tell a story or raise awareness.
2. Examine the work of Dorothea Lange (Great Depression), Sebastiao Salgado (environment), and modern photojournalists.
3. Discuss the ethics of documentary photography: consent, representation, truth.
4. Teach composition techniques: rule of thirds, leading lines, framing, perspective.
5. Discuss how captions and sequencing create narrative in a photo essay.
6. Students choose a local environmental topic for their photo essay.
7. Plan a shot list: What images will tell the story?
8. Go on a photography walk to capture images.
9. Select and sequence the best 5-8 images.
10. Write captions that add context and meaning to each photograph.

slides.heading: Documentary Photography
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to be learning about: documentary photography. Think of it like being a visual detective, where you use your camera to find and share real stories happening around you, instead of just taking pictures of your friends smiling. It's all about capturing moments that mean something and can make people think or feel.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather examples of documentary photography appropriate for the age group. Prepare composition guide with rule of thirds grid. Charge cameras or tablets. Print photo essay planning templates.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is telling us what we need to get ready. We've got a camera or tablet to take pictures, some examples of real documentary photos to look at for inspiration, a guide to help us with how to frame our shots, a planning sheet to help organize our ideas, and pencils for writing. You'll want to grab all these things, and maybe ask a grown-up to help make sure your camera is charged and everything is ready to go.

slides.text: Documentary photography captures real life — not posed or staged. It tells stories, preserves history, and can inspire action. Dorothea Lange's Depression-era photographs helped pass laws to help migrant workers. Images have power.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step explains the core idea of documentary photography: it's about capturing real, unposed moments. Think about how a photo of someone laughing naturally looks way more interesting than a picture where everyone is told to say "cheese!" These kinds of photos can actually help people understand important issues, just like the photos from a long time ago showed everyone what life was like for people who didn't have much.

slides.text: Composition makes the difference between a snapshot and a photograph. RULE OF THIRDS: Imagine your frame divided into a 3x3 grid. Place key subjects along the lines or at intersections. LEADING LINES: Use paths, fences, or rivers to guide the viewer's eye.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're talking about how to make our photos look really good, which is called composition. The "rule of thirds" is like drawing an invisible tic-tac-toe board over your picture and putting the important stuff where the lines cross – it makes the photo more interesting. "Leading lines" are things like roads or fences that naturally draw your eye through the picture, like a path leading you into the story.

slides.text: Ethics matter: Always ask permission before photographing people. Represent your subject honestly — do not manipulate images to change the story. Your goal is truth, not drama. A good documentary photographer respects their subjects.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important part: ethics. It means being a good and honest photographer. You always need to ask people if it's okay to take their picture, and you should never change the photo later to make it look like something it's not. The goal is to show the truth about what you're photographing, and that means respecting the people and places you capture.

slides.text: A photo essay is a series of photographs that tell a story together. Like a written essay, it has a beginning (establishing shot), middle (details and evidence), and end (closing image). Captions provide context the image alone cannot convey.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, a photo essay is like telling a story using a series of pictures, almost like a comic book but with real photos. Each picture adds a piece to the story, and the captions are like the words that explain what's happening or give you extra information you wouldn't know just by looking. It's how you build a whole narrative from start to finish.

slides.prompt: Create a photo essay on a local environmental topic (a park, garden, stream, construction site, recycling center, or your own yard). Plan your shot list first: What story do you want to tell? Take at least 15 photographs using composition techniques. Select your best 5-8 images and arrange them in narrative order. Write a caption for each photo (1-2 sentences) that adds information beyond what the viewer can see. Give your photo essay a title.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the photographer and storyteller! First, pick a local place that has an environmental story, like a park or even your own backyard, and think about what story you want to tell there. Then, make a list of the shots you want to get, take at least 15 photos using those composition tricks we learned, and then choose the best 5 to 8 photos that tell your story in order. Finally, write a couple of sentences for each picture to explain it.

slides.text: Documentary photography combines artistic vision with social purpose. Your photo essays document something real about your environment and your perspective. Share them with your family and discuss: What story did you choose to tell, and why?
slides.mastery_check: Can the student apply composition techniques, create a coherent photo essay with narrative structure, and write informative captions?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're wrapping up by celebrating the awesome photo essays you've created! You've learned how to capture real moments, use cool techniques to make your photos look professional, and tell a whole story with just pictures and a few words. Think about the story you chose to tell and why it's important – you've really done some great work capturing your environment!

parent_notes: Documentary photography is a powerful medium for developing visual literacy, critical thinking, and environmental awareness. The composition techniques (rule of thirds, leading lines) apply to all photography and visual art. The ethics discussion is age-appropriate and important — children should learn to be thoughtful about how they represent others. If your child does not have access to a camera, a smartphone works perfectly. Consider displaying their photo essay at home or sharing it with family as a finished artistic work.
